ATTENTION SHS STUDENTS AND FAMILIES:

We are so excited to welcome you back next week! A few quick reminders so we can ensure as smooth of a return to school as possible.

1- Please check your school email (ssdcosmos) in the upcoming days (BEFORE Tuesday, September 8th). Teachers will be reaching out to you through this email address to let you know what the expectations are for the first week of school.

2- Please remember that you will be expected to wear a mask while you are in the school building. We will have some masks available if you do not have one that has been approved as a suitable facial covering. Be advised that gators are NOT an approved facial covering at this time.

3 - Please remember to be aware of social distancing expectations when you are at school. We know you will be excited to see friends that you may not have seen for a while, but we ask that you adhere to the 6 ft social distancing rules.

Again, we are so excited to welcome you back, and we are looking forward to a great 2020-2021 school year!

Good afternoon Springfield parents and students. This is Zach McLaughlin, the Superintendent of Schools. I am calling this afternoon to clarify the current food delivery process. Despite the fact that school has ended, we continue to follow the same food delivery procedure through the end of the month. We are still delivering to all the same locations in the same way. This will continue through Friday, June 26th. On that delivery day next Friday, we will include meals that also cover Monday, the 29th, and Tuesday, the 30th.

During the week of June 29th through July 3rd, there will be no deliveries as we transition to our new food service company Abbey Services. Then on July 6th we will be up and running again, but we will in a new format. We hope to have more information out to you about that shortly.

Thank you and enjoy the rest of this beautiful afternoon.

CLARITY ON FINAL STUDENT DATES!
While we will be sending out an email with more district updates at the end of the week, we wanted to get out the shift in our end of the school year date right away.

Up until just recently, we thought that we were looking at ending either on June 12th or 16th. Well, the situation has changed. In the last few days, we have received notification of state waivers for the following missed school days:

1. March 16 & 17--With COVID cases in Greater Springfield, we closed two days before the Governor closed all Vermont schools on March 18th. Those days are waived.
2. Our three snow days--The student days are waived in this case in exchange for staff only days for planning and training in anticipation of next fall.

As a result, our end of the year dates have shifted. Here is our schedule:
LAST STUDENT DAY: June 9th
STAFF PLANNING/TRAINING June 11, 12, & 15

SHS Alumni Spotlight presents Musician Ben Fuller, graduate of 2005!

"Music has taken my life and made it into something I never would have dreamed; Except I dreamed about it a lot. I grew up in Southern Vermont, on our family dairy farm, where I learned how to work and saw first hand, my father’s passion. I started singing at a young age to pass the time while I worked, and the song never stopped, and somewhere between the farm and college, I picked up a guitar.

Fast forward to 2015, came a beautiful and devastating drug-fueled relationship which led me to understand better, the other side of the disease. And then 2017, which changed my entire outlook on life, I fell face-first into my music, after losing my best friend to a drug overdose, and I began writing. In late 2018, with a fire to help others who struggled with addiction, I moved to Nashville, Tennessee to pursue my career as a singer/songwriter. Today, my heart continues to fill with the stories of loss and hope and love all across our country, as I travel to sing my story, as well as the stories of those who can’t."

post_text: Mrs. Fraser’s class recently read a book called Going Places written by Paul Renolds. This book was about how students in a classroom all receive the exact same building kit to make a go-Kart. By the end of the book, they learned that most of the go-karts looked the same, but not all of them. They had a discussion about how even when you are given the exact same building supplies as everyone else, not everyone's “inventions” will turn out looking the same. The student’s in Mrs. Fraser’s class were then given building kits to create something as a team. In the kits the students were given marshmallows, toothpicks, popsicle sticks, tape, scissors and string. After spending 30 minutes to build, each team was able to share about what they made from their building kit. They had a lot of fun making our inventions!

post_text: Every Thursday, Ms. Tucker's class tries to get outside to spend time in nature. This past Thursday the students had their first experience "Slow Birding." This is where you sit quietly in the same spot for about 20 minutes (once a week or everyday). This gives the birds a chance to get used to you and become comfortable. Each time you notice sights, smells, and sounds. Students were documenting things they saw and heard. They were also making a list of questions about what we weren't seeing and reasons why.

post_text: Second graders were thrilled to explore erosion hands-on during their field trip to the Quechee Gorge on Friday! We saw evidence of huge changes in the Earth over time. Students got to walk down to the bottom of the gorge and see how the Ottauquechee River carved out the land. They also saw the human-made dam, which creates a waterfall and provides power to the residents of Quechee! Students got to ask questions about erosion of our wonderful tour guide and park interpreter, Anastasia Mickiewicz. We won't soon forget our trip to the gorge!

CRASE Information Night

Good afternoon parents and guardians of Springfield School District students,

This is Zach McLaughlin, the Superintendent of Schools. I am calling to let you know about an important informational event on Wednesday night. Over the course of the last year, the district has been changing its model of response to a potential active shooter event. In conjunction with local first responders, we have been working to train staff in the approach known as the Civilian Response to Active Shooter Events (CRASE). As we continue our process to make this change, we want to be sure to keep you aware of the program and how we are trying to keep the school community safe.

On Wednesday night at 7 PM in the high school auditorium, District Safety Coordinator Kevin Anderson, District Psychologist Kristen Hurd, and I will be joined by Springfield Fire Chief Russ Thompson and Springfield Police Chief Mark Fountain to discuss CRASE and answer your questions. We hope that you can join us Wednesday at 7PM. Thank you and have a great rest of your day.

post_text: PLN Time! Day 3 & 4 of New Teacher Orientation! New recruits have started working with our inhouse teacher trainers (Amanda Frank of SHS & Erin Rounds of Union Street) to start engaging our common approach to pedagogy. Our approach is grounded in our partnership with the Penn Literacy Network (PLN) at the University of Pennsylvania. Once taught by outside PLN instructors our PLN 1 Course is now taught by these veteran staff members trained and collaborating with PLN. For more information on PLN, check out this short video: https://youtu.be/7irsDRzCOUk

Great stuff happening downtown. The SPACE (Springfield Peer and Community Engagement)initiative is up and running on Main Street. A wonderful collection of staff (especially Ms. Stagner, Mr. Lievense, and Ms. Polk), student, and adult community partners are making this youth bridge to the community-at-large possible. Thanks also go out to the Vermont Community Fund for their support. Yesterday, the group was hard at work on taking next steps. You'll find The SPACE right next to Flying Crowing Coffee. For more info on the SPACE, check out the following article from the Eagle Times.
